fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5|titleBGColor=#3C78B5|bgColor=#E7F4FA}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Server.

We spend a significant amount of time on an ongoing basis to determine our product investments in Bitbucket Server. Unfortunately, we are not currently planning to address this suggestion in the next 12 months. In the last 12 months, we've resolved 10 of the top 30 feature requests, and our upcoming roadmap includes a number of other top voted suggestions, including in-browser editing, improvements to search functionality, better JIRA integration, and providing an even better code review experience.

I understand that this may be disappointing, but we believe it’s important for us to be open, honest and transparent with our customers. Product feedback is collected from a number of different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Norman Ma

Product Manager - Bitbucket Server
{panel}

As a _way more comfortable and straightforward_ alternative to messing around with {{.mailmap}} files, please add the "Username aliases" feature in Stash that's already existing in BitBucket.

Implement this on a per-repository, per-project as well as system-wide level as well as for users' personal repositories. Providing buttons to move a created alias to either of the other levels could ease management of this a lot.

This will also actually extend functionality because right now in 2.12.1, Stash apparently ignores globally configured {{.mailmap}} files – confirmed by Stash support – but only cares about {{.mailmap}} files inside repos.

I personally think it's a very bad idea to mix up code and some configuration that has nothing to do with it, so I'd never commit a {{.mailmap}} file directly into a repository. With a mapping feature built into Stash, the configuration would be separate from the repo files. Also, even if Stash cared about globally-set {{.mailmap}} files, bigger organizations with strict permissions could also profit from this since their server admin no longer needs to fumble around with files directly on the command line every time something needs to be changed but can do it in a few clicks in the interface – or, with Stash's global/project-level permissions, even delegate that to certain other people.

The highest priority should be on the system-level aliases, second come project-level and repository-level aliases, then personal user repositories.

As for permissions, this scheme might be a good starting point for brainstorming the perfect solution:
 - Repository admins may add, edit and delete aliases set up for their repos
 - Project admins may add, edit and delete aliases set up for their projects and any repos in those projects
 - Stash admins may add, edit and delete aliases set up globally as well as for any project and any repo inside those
 - Moving aliases to a different level is possible whenever the user has the permissions needed to manage aliases on the target level, e.g. project admins may move a repo-level alias inside one of their repos to project-level, but repo admins may not do so.

For personal user repositories, maybe have a toggle to switch system-level aliases on/off (in user settings, one toggle for all of the user's repos).
fields.summary: Committer alias management

fields.description:
I noticed you'll always land on the "Files" tab per default when clicking a link to a repository, and as far as I could see, this is not configurable at all.
Personally, I'd rather have the Overview tab being shown first to everyone per default, since that's also the place where all the info documents (readmes) are shown, and in general I think every user should be able to configure that as they like, overriding the system default.

In short: It would be very nice to be able to configure the tab you land on first:
- globally (system admin)
- per repository (system admin, project admin)
- per user (personal settings)
(Order of importance descending)
fields.summary: Ability to configure default landing tab for repositories

fields.description:
It is very difficult when looking at a pull request to figure out what comments you have read. You can look at the activity stream to get some idea, but if the comment is a response to a previous comment, you basically have to scroll through the entire activity log which can be quite long. 

We often have pull requests that have 20 or more comments. At this point, it become difficult to keep track of.

I noticed there is now a count of comments for a pull request. It would be nice if there was a similar count of unread comments and some additional indication of unread comments on maybe the diff tab on a per file basis. This functionality is available in Crucible and our team members are used to having this feature. Not having it in Stash makes it difficult to use and some members are at the point they rather use Crucible for reviews.

This feature could probably also be expanded to non-pull request comments too (i.e., commit comments).

Thanks,
Dave Humeniuk
fields.summary: Ability to keep track of unread comments in a pull request

fields.description:
Setting up Stash over https via a reverse-proxy should result in loading avatars from a secure URL, however this is not the case. For example under Project Permissions, still the http:// URL is used to fetch the avatars.

*Steps to reproduce*
# Configure Stash to run through a reverse proxy ([https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Integrating+Stash+with+Apache+HTTP+Server]), but set the scheme to https and port to 443
# Define the base URL accordingly, to have a https:// URL
# Create an user, default pic will be from gavatar
# Notice that on the administration page, the secure URL is used to access the avatar
# Navigate to *Project > Settings > Permissions*, add the newly created user, notice that the URL for the avatar is not the secure one

*Workaround*
Add the following lines to {{<STASH_HOME>/stash-config.properties}} and restart the instance:
{noformat}
avatar.url.format.http=https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/%1$s.jpg?s=%2$d&d=%3$s
avatar.url.format.https=https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/%1$s.jpg?s=%2$d&d=%3$s
{noformat}

*Correction*
The above configuration is _not_ proper. The correct configuration also sets {{secure="true"}} on the connector, not just {{sheme="https"}}. Setting only one or the other will result in incorrect URLs.
fields.summary: Stash serves avatars over http instead of https, even if reverse-proxy configured properly

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of April 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi all,

I'm excited to share that in Bitbucket Server 7.1 we shipped *Push log* feature that allows admins to see the history of all push events in a repository.

You can find more information in the Bitbucket Server 7.1 [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-1-release-notes-998641213.html] and Push log [docs|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/push-logs-998882984.html].

Please, don't hesitate to leave feedback on the feature in the comments. This will help us to priorities further development.

Anton Genkin
 Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel}
*Original message*

As and administrator, I would like to be able to have push events moved to a higher priority so I do not have to set my audit log capture to low in order to get these events.

Since Git allows users to specify what they wish in their .gitconfig file for user name, it is at the Stash authentication level for push events that we consider the audit point for determining who is responsible for a set of changes. If you push it, even if you don't author it, you are considered the owner of the changes. The audit log feature for Stash does allow us to capture this information so we can tie the push of particular commits to the Stash authenticated user. The push events, however are classified as low priority so unless we are missing something, we need to set the audit log level to low. This would then capture many events that we are not interested in. From our standpoint and the need for more stringent audit trails, we feel that push events should be classified at more than a 'low' priority.
fields.summary: Increase priority of push events for Audit Log

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

As an admin, it would be good if I could export/import one single project/repo of my instance and its associated content (i.e. Pull Requests) especially when a step-by-step migration is required. This would also be handy in case a repository is accidentally deleted from your instance and you need to restore it.
 Currently it is only possible to backup and/or restore the Bitbucket Server instance as a whole. Please refer to our [Data recovery and backups document for more details|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Data+recovery+and+backups].
h3. Suggested Solution

Provide the possibility to export and restore projects and/or repositories individually.
fields.summary: As an admin, I want to be able to export and restore projects or repositories individually, so that the metainformation (e.g. pull requests details) are preserved

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Status –  September 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for providing your thoughts and votes on this suggestion. We know it's been a while since this suggestion was raised and we're sorry to have kept you without a clear answer.

Your feedback has helped us better understand the challenges have with Ctrl+F in pull requests. Despite our lack of communication, this problem is actually one of those areas we plan to improve in mid-term.

Thank you again for all your feedback on this suggestion and we're looking forward to give you more updates as we work on the solution.

Best,
 Anton Genkin | Bitbucket Product Manager
{panel}
*Original message*

The stash pull request diff view (both side-by-side and unified) break page search due to their fancy javascript-based scrolling. Only the visible region (plus a bit extra) of the diff is stored in the DOM, so your browser's search can only find stuff in that visible region. This is premature optimization: A web browser can easily hold the entire DOM tree for the diff between multi-thousand line files.

Related to this: a number of our developers have had issues with diffs not scrolling properly.
fields.summary: Code search UX issues on diff views

My profile icon on the top right shows a big red "20" to indicate 20 open PRs that I need to review, but clicking it to show the list only gives a list of 10.  I see no way to expand this list to fetch the rest of the 20, or to scroll downward for it to lazyload the rest of the list, or to page.

I went back to open the view as a visual aid while entering this request info, and now the full list is displayed.  Hence, it appears to be an intermittent issue.  I confirmed with one other frequent user that he's seen this occasionally also.  So, I've updated my verbiage here to indicate its intermittent trait.  I can't really imagine in my mind an implementation of that functionality that could result in that kind of intermittent behavior, but perhaps your folks will immediately recognize some potential possibilities.

This option does not work if an extra space is added to the end of the line.

{noformat:title=stash-config.properties}
plugin.stash-scm-git.pullrequest.merge.strategy.ANDROID=ff-only  
plugin.stash-scm-git.pullrequest.merge.strategy.IOS=ff-only  
{noformat}

When defining the parameters above [as defined in our documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Stash+config+properties#Stashconfigproperties-Pullrequests], the option won't work if that there are spaces at the end of the above lines settings in your {{stash-config.properties}}. 

*Fix:* Remove the extra spaces at the end of the lines and restart Stash.

Currently our development team leaders are shunning Access Keys and are using "users" in Stash to allow access to outside systems (Bamboo, Fisheye, Wally etc...).

Their argument is that by including these users in a "development-agents" group in Stash, it makes it much easier to manage the access that these system accounts have. i.e. when you create a new project, just add the "development-agents" group as a "read-only" user and you are set.

The alternative in this situation would be to add each access key with read-only access to the project.

Additionally, they point out that in the situation where access needs to be revoked for a particular system account, the user simply needs to be removed from the "development-agents" group. Whereas in the case that we had been using "Access Keys" we would have to get each Proejct Administrator to remove the access key from the Project and/or repository.

This last one is somewhat mitigated with the latest feature in 2.12.1 which shows where an access key is being used, prior to deletion.

As such, could you please put in a mechanism to be able to "group" access keys, so that they can be more easily managed.
fields.summary: Add ability to group Access Keys

fields.description:
There are some classes in the {{com.atlassian.stash:stash-func-test-browser}} module that would be handy for plugin developers to use. Notably, {{it.com.atlassian.stash.BaseFuncTest}} and its friends.

Because the {{stash-func-test-browser}} module is not compiled by the default Maven profile, it is excluded from the release build. This means that the artifact is never published to https://maven.atlassian.com, making it impossible to re-use outside of the Stash core source tree.

Could you please consider either adding this module to the release build, or moving the functionality of {{BaseFuncTest}} into another location that is accessible to third-party developers? <3
fields.summary: Publish it.com.atlassian.stash.BaseFuncTest for plugin developers

fields.description:
When I load Stash pull request links when my session has expired, it kicks me to the login page and appears to store the originally requested URL in a session parameter. Unfortunately, this breaks what I think is a fairly normal workflow:

1. First thing in the morning, look at new emails from Stash, command-click on links in those emails to open them in browser tabs
2. Realize that my session has expired, go to first tab and log in
3. Stash redirects me to the last clicked link and the rest of the tabs have completely lost the information on the originally requested link :(

By contrast, let's take a look at another Atlassian product, JIRA. When I request a JIRA URL with no valid session, I'm taken to a URL like this:

https://jira.mycompany.com/login.jsp?permissionViolation=true&os_destination=%2Fbrowse%2FXX-123

Notice how the return path is encoded in the URL, so I can open many JIRA links before logging in, and after logging in all of them will redirect to the correct place.

This behavior would be very desirable in Stash and would make JIRA and Stash more consistent.
fields.summary: Stash should store "return to" destination in URL rather than session

fields.description: We should allow support of git merge drivers on a repo-by-repo basis for PRs and branch model auto merges. This may be tricky to do as under the hood we use merging to calculate the effective diff for PRs and you'd probably want to see the effective diff unmolested by the merge driver but then perform the merge using the merge driver.
fields.summary: Add support for merge drivers when merging PRs ideally on a repo-by-repo bases

fields.description:
We are just starting to use pull requests and have noticed that for several pull requests we have done, the first comment of the pull request is shown against the wrong version of the code. It does not show OUTDATED like subsequent comments which are linked to the correct version of the code.

As an example:
1. We created a pull request
2. The only reviewer commented on a line and asked why NULL was being passed in as arguments. 
3. The creator of the pull request then put a comment near/on the same line to explain why and that they will change it to pass in a value. 
4. A new commit was made which changed that line to have a value. 
5. When we look at the overview tab of the pull request. We can see that the first comment is against the latest code so is wrong. While the second comment is against the original code which is correct.
fields.summary: First comment on pull request is shown against wrong version of code

fields.description:
The {{DefaultRefSyncConfig}} does not shutdown the thread pool it creates.

Note that the threads it generates are marked as _daemon_, thus this won't prevent the shutdown of Stash.

In the highly unusual scenario where the plugin would be _manually stopped and re-started_, this would mean that the threads stay alive until Stash finally shutdowns.
fields.summary: The refsync plugin is not shutting down its thread pool

fields.description:
What would be really nice is if there's code detected on the ticket level in the Source tab block a transition if a Pull Request has not been submitted. Similar to how you can block a transition if a code review in Crucible hasn't been completed yet.
This would prevent developers from moving their tickets when they have not submitted a pull request. You could also do one better and have the transition fire off an automatic pull request for the branch that is identified in the Source tab (if that still will exist with Stash).
fields.summary: Block JIRA issue transitions based on Stash events (eg a PR hasn't been created)

fields.description:
Splitting out this specific request from STASH-2754...

"In general, a pull request will probably be related to some particular issue. During development, there will be some comments relating to speccing out the issue and probably some code-review type comments on the pull request itself. It would be beyond convenient if all of those were connected into one discussion. There might be multiple pull requests involved in a single issue, and they should be linked with statuses on the issue itself.
It's a pain to have the discussion, code review, and resolution split between the issue and the pull request. They need to all be integrated together."
fields.summary: Show all issue, commit and PR comments related to a JIRA issue in one discussion stream

fields.description:
On Windows Server 2008 R2 with Stash version 2.11.2 and 2.12.1 with msysGit 1.9.0-preview20140217 cloning pegs out the CPU to 100% and runs endlessly. Only action is to restart the Stash Windows Service. Pushing and Pull worked fine for two weeks, until we tried to clone. Windows Service is using a Standard User ( not Administrator ).

When we downgraded to msysGit 1.8.1.2-preview20130201 cloning worked again.
fields.summary: Cloning on Windows with msysGit 1.9.x Fails

fields.description:
In a pull request, it would be useful that any 'Approve' votes would be retracted, such that it is absolutely impossible to push any commits to master that have not been peer reviewed yet.

Otherwise, one could give approval, the developer could (unintentionally) add malicious code in new commits, and merge it onto master.

This auto-retracting of approval votes may not be required in many environments though, but for some it would be very useful. Therefore I suggest you make it a configurable option, perhaps configurable per destination branch (only for merges onto master).
fields.summary: Automatically retract approval if a pull request is updated with new commits

fields.description:
It would be nice to have a way to import to Bitbucket Server the already closed pull requests from GitHub Enterprise so that they would be easily viewable from the Stash Web UI. 

GitHub Enterprise already allows to export the pull requests with all respective data.
fields.summary: Import review history from other repository managers

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Data Center.

We spend a significant amount of time determining our product investments in Bitbucket Data Center. Unfortunately, we are not planning to address this suggestion in the next 12 months. In the last year, we have resolved many of the highly voted suggestions like Reviewer groups, Pull request templates, capability to enable/disable source branch deletion on merging pull requests and our upcoming roadmap includes a number of other top voted suggestions, including repository archiving. Please check out our [public roadmap|https://www.atlassian.com/roadmap/data-center?product=bitbucket] for more details on the coming soon and future items.

I understand that this may be disappointing, but it’s important for us to be open, honest, and transparent with our customers. Product feedback is collected from many different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,

Imran Khan

Product Manager - Bitbucket Data Center & Server
{panel}
*Original request description*

This is a follow up to issue -STASH-3314- that was closed. In that issue Jens Schumacher said that the reason why multiline comments were not added is because in Crucible it was very hard to select actual code, with what I agree, but I would like to suggest an improvement.

Why not make it that way that when you select code, it regulary selects text as it is now in Stash, but if you would like to leave a comment on multiple lines, you click on the line numbers on the left of the code. This would make it the best of both worlds.
fields.summary: Pull Request Multiline Comments

fields.description:
We use fusion create branch pretty extensively. The auto generated PR names from branches introduce a lot of noise into the PR name, e.g.

issue/FUSE-906-execute-transitions-without-executing

becomes

Issue/FUSE-906 execute transitions without executing

Would be nice if it was just:

Execute transitions without executing

given we can get to the issue via the link and the PR type could be displayed elsewhere.
fields.summary: Smarter pull request name generation

fields.description:
Confluence has a lot of pull requests. I wish I could sort the view by Author and Destination quite often. 

Even cooler would be if i could see all of my team member's PRs somehow.
fields.summary: Wish there was sort on headers for pull requests view

fields.description:
I would like to get hold of the permlinks to comments on commits and pull requests from within the web interface.

The auto-generated emails when someone comments on a pull request (either on lines of code or just on the pull request generally) contain a link to take you to the specific comment, so the permlinks already exist, but when I am just browsing through a commit/pull request it would be nice to easily fetch the permlink and not have to go back into emails to find the link.  Also, stash may be configured to not send the commenter an email when they comment, so they won't always have the email containing the link.

This is typically implemented in your other products as a chain-link symbol alongside the edit and delete links, which can be right-clicked to retrieve the permlink URL
fields.summary: Expose permlinks for Comments on Pull Requests and Commits in web interface

fields.description:
When including an inline link on a markdown page with empty parentheses the markdown page will load forever when opened.

To reproduce:
# Create a markdown page with a link as follows:
{code}
A direct testlink without a url [test]()
{code}
# Open it and see the spinner rolling forever

Expected:
A page to be rendered or atleast some feedback. Github shows the parent folder.
Strangely the README.md is not affected
fields.summary: Markdown pages with inline markdown links and empty parentheses load indefinitely

fields.description: Since 2.12.0 sources have SNAPSHOT prefix in pom.xml. This cause problem with debug in IDE. Plugin can't linked to sources, cos plugin have 2.12.1 in version. If i will use 2.12.1-SNAPSHOT in plugin's pom.xml, then atlas-debug stop working.
fields.summary: Wrong version 2.12.1-SNAPSHOT in sources

fields.description: It would be really cool if i could look in Stash on a Repository that is referenced as a submodules in many project and see the references each parent has to the specific submodule so maybe there is away i could get overview and tell people, hey we made these changes go and upgrade to this commit because you are way behind. I think this could be very useful.
fields.summary: Show parent references in Submodules

fields.description: It stays on the current commit hash instead of going to the commit hash I clicked.
fields.summary: Command click / middle click / Open in new tab not working for History dropdown on view source of file

fields.description:
After I change a permission on a branch (e.g. add someone to restricted list), refreshing the page re-attempts the edit request and displays the Edit dialog. It would be nicer from the usability point to not have to change the url in the browser to get rid of that.

To reproduce: go into branch permissions via the branch actions menu in the branch list (this adds the ?at= parameter that hangs around afterwards)
fields.summary: Refreshing Branch Permissions page after editing permission, re-attempts the change request

fields.description: After removing users from the list of reviewers on a pull request, they still receive email notifications about new comments and changes.
fields.summary: Reviewers removed from Pull Requests still receive emails

fields.description: I am using Jira + Stash.  I am able to create a new branch from a Jira issue by clicking on the "Create Branch" link.  If I create the branch under a forked repo owned by myself, the new branch will not be listed in the Jira issue.  Only branches in normal stash repos are listed.
fields.summary: branches in forked repo are not listed in the issue

fields.description: Often there are projects and repos with names that get truncated in the repository search, where the project name start of the repo name is the same it is impossible to distinguish one from another without hovering for the element title.
fields.summary: Repository quick search results don't distinguish long repo names with the same prefix
Navigating to the account page when the user is not logged in redirects to the project list

fields.description:
The create branch screen (from Jira) comes up with:
{noformat}
Repo: (our repo)
Branch type: Bugfix
Branch from: develop
Branch name: bugfix/<PRJ>-<ID>-<name>
{noformat}

It would be better to start with:
{noformat}
Repo: (our repo)
Branch type: Feature
Branch from: develop
Branch name: bugfix/<PRJ>-<ID>-<name>
{noformat}

and then if you change "feature" to "bugfix" it should automatically change
from to "Release", hotfix should change from to master and so forth.  Or if you change the from then the type should change automatically.  Maybe have a "Link type to from" checkbox that people could uncheck if they don't want the above to be automated.
fields.summary: When creating branch via Jira it would be nice to pre-select both develop and feature and auto change type when you change from.

fields.description:
Unified diff scrolling frequently:

* doesn't scroll at all,
* scrolls a small distance, then jumps back to its original position,
* scrolls horizontally when I'm only scrolling vertically, or
* scrolls in the opposite direction.

This happens to me dozens of times a week. Refreshing the page usually fixes it, but not always. I use Chrome; let me know if there's any other information I can give to help diagnose the problems.
fields.summary: Unified diff scrolling is buggy when using the trackpad

fields.description:
Hi there,

By default the notifications in a room in HipChat has the notify parameter set as off (see API documentation: https://www.hipchat.com/docs/api/method/rooms/message).

It would be useful to be able to toggle that flag in the HipChat integration settings.
fields.summary: Configure hipchat notifications to toggle whether users in room are "notified"

fields.description:
when calling this web service: {{/rest/api/1.0/projects/PROJECT_KEY/repos/REPOSITORY_SLUG/commits}} it would be nice there was a query parameter or something that would have each commit list it's changes like this: {{/rest/api/1.0/projects/PROJECT_KEY/repos/REPOSITORY_SLUG/commits/COMMIT_ID/changes}} service. 

We use the rest api quite a bit to integrate with some of our other developer tooling and one of our use cases is to get the list of commits between what's in our QA environment and Production and we would like to be able to quickly filter that list to filter out test only changes for example. The only way to do this right now would be to make a service call for each commit which would obviously not perform well.
fields.summary: commits REST service should optionally be able to include change data

fields.description:
Hi,

we are getting this error msg even though in "global admissions individual users" there are only 8 users.

Thanks
Denny
fields.summary: Error msg "You have more users than your license allows. Pushing is disabled."

fields.description:
The Settings->Repository details tab of each repository lists a setting:

    Default branch

With a selector containing all branches.  The comment for this field is:

    Select the default branch for browsing the repository. By default, Git chooses "master".

This is correct, but misleading as this value actually changes the active brnach and thus impacts which branch is checked out when a user does a plain:

    git clone <repo>

The comment (and perhaps the field name) need adjusted to make it clear this is more than just a UI setting, this has already caused one of our users to incorrectly change the setting not realising it impacted cloning of the repository company wide.
fields.summary: Comment on repository settings entry for "Default branch" are confusing

fields.description:
In Github, you can link to headers using anchor tags. For example, http://developer.github.com/v3/gists/#get-a-single-gist takes me to a particular point in the page as opposed to just the overall document.

This doesn't seem to exist in stash as you render all headers as header elements. Would it be difficult to add an anchor tag inside these?
fields.summary: Link to headers in markdown via anchor tags

fields.description:
Google's source tree is managed via multiple git project using a tool called {{repo}}. More information about it can be found here: [http://source.android.com/source/downloading.html]

It would be desirable for FishEye to support this, whereas there are multiple git repositories and make them searchable as if it is one single git repository (in reality there are multiple git repositories). FishEye should be able to index all repositories in one manifest as one single repository and provide all the features accordingly.
fields.summary: Support Google's repo

fields.description:
The API documentation and/or release notes should document the changes to Changeset.getAuthor().getName() in 2.12 as a result of STASH-3235

Original request:

Hi guys,

It seems that in Stash 2.12 there was a change in what Changeset.getAuthor().getName() returns. Previously it used to return the person's full name (as specified by the user.name in git, e.g. "Igor Sereda"), and now it returns the user's login name (e.g. "sereda"). 

I didn't see any mentions of this in the release notes, nor do I observe any changes in the javadocs.

This change currently breaks my plugin that is used to verify that the incoming push contains changesets that are created by the users with the names and emails that exist in the system. 

Could you please let me know if this is a bug and you're going to revert the change, or if it is an intentional change?

(In the latter case, could you please advise how can I retrieve the full name of the person who's the author of the changeset? Or maybe you have incorporated these checks that I do into Stash?)

It would be great to see Developer Release Notes for new versions that would mention the breaking API changes.

Thanks!
Igor
fields.summary: Document changed behavior of Changeset.getAuthor().getName() in 2.12 public API

fields.description:
When selecting the Clone button in the repository webpage for a project the provided URL includes my user name.  At least on a Windows system this user name is not required when using Windows Credential Manager to supply your password.  Further more if someone uses that URL in a submodule it will not work correctly for other users.  

It would be nice to have the option to suppress the username in the URL.  This could be a global setting for the Stash instance.
fields.summary: Remove username in https clone URL

fields.description: Over the last two weeks, I've noticed that scrolling through code reviews has been janky. I'm not sure if there is a scroll handler firing somewhere that needs to be debounced or if it's the line highlight/icon hover action that's making it choppy.
fields.summary: Scrolling code reviews seems to have more jank

fields.description:
On my 15-inch MBP screen, there just isn't enough horizontal space for me to ever want to keep the changed files panel open. I always end up having to perform an extra step to close it.

Ideally, the panel would revert to its previous state (whether it was collapsed or expanded) when I switch back to unified diff.
fields.summary: Automatically collapse changed files panel when switching from unified diff to side-by-side diff

fields.description:
In Stash 2.12.0, the inbox icon in the upper-right corner does not show up on the home page ("http://url/projects"). The link also doesn't popup the pull request workbox. See the attachment for a screenshot.

The icon and link seem to work properly on all other pages. The rendered HTML is different on this one page.

I tried in multiple browsers and cleared cache, but it still doesn't work.
fields.summary: Inbox icon missing on Stash home page

fields.description:
Some days ago we had commend it a pull request (on a line of code) that lead to much confusion:

{quote}Bla bla bla bla List<Object> bla bla bla...{quote}

The problem is that it was cut of after "List" because the "<Object>" part was interpreted as a HTML tag. The other developers where confused about that useless comment...

Looks like the data-text attribute on the div is populated in the correct way, but the p-tag misses the rest of the message.
fields.summary: Comments are not escaped properly

fields.description:
I guess this is not a common request, but I'd like to have the option to show the README file before the list of folders/files inside the repository. 

If you have a larger number of folders, the README is not visible unless you scroll the page. Even if there was some sort of "expand" box to read the full content of the README file, that would be a good improvement.
fields.summary: More visible README file

fields.description: Certain types of errors during database migration or setup are incorrectly handled, resulting in them being wrapped in a blanket "A database error has occurred" message which hides all the useful details. This also prevents the details from appearing in the logfiles, making such failures difficult to track down and fix.
fields.summary: Migration/Setup: "A database error has occurred" masks useful failure details

h4. Cause

This issue affects all versions of Stash from 2.5.0 through the just released 2.12.0. It is 100% MySQL-specific, and should not affect customers using any other database.

h4. Solution

Upgrade to the indicated fix releases.

h4. Workaround

Exactly because of this issue and [STASH-4701|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-4701], we recommend that customers with larger instances (you can consider that 500+ licenses) move off MySQL (you can see the warning we placed on [Connecting Stash to MySQL|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Connecting+Stash+to+MySQL]). Therefore, if you can move to an alternative database (for example, PostgreSQL) in case you don't want to upgrade now, that'd also solve this issue for you.

Leaving as-is will cause you performance issues as well as Pull Requests misbehaviour while merging. For instance:
{quote}
(...)the following error more and more frequently when trying to merge a PR from the Stash UI (happening on multiple repos): "New changes were pushed to master in project/repo while the merge was being performed. Please retry the merge."
{quote}

The good news is that Stash makes it really easy for you to migrate databases. All you have to do is:

- *Preparation:* configure a PostgreSQL db (it can be any other [supported databases|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Supported+platforms]) as described on [Connecting Stash to PostgreSQL|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Connecting+Stash+to+PostgreSQL]
- *Migration:* migrate your instance data over to PostgreSQL as described on [Connecting Stash to an external database|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Connecting+Stash+to+an+external+database]
{quote}
*To run the Database Migration Wizard:*

# Log in to Stash.
# In the administration area, click Database (under 'Settings').
# Click Migrate database and follow the instructions for running the migration.
{quote}
fields.summary: Empty activity deletion deadlocks on MySQL

fields.description:
If I want to link to this page on wikipedia, I can't: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/You_aren't_gonna_need_it

It's because of the apostrophe in the URL.

If I write the following markdown: {code}Yay for [YAGNI](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/You_aren't_gonna_need_it)!{code}

I end up with an <a> with no link.
fields.summary: Markdown links have overly aggressive XSS protection?

fields.description:
We are using both HTTP(s) and SSH to allow people to clone repositories from our Stash installation. Since we have integrated Bamboo and Stash using SSH keys, every Stash project has at least one SSH access key.

This causes the Stash UI to present SSH as the default clone URL type while we want our users to use HTTP(s) by default.
fields.summary: Show HTTP as the default when the user hasn't uploaded an SSH key

fields.description:
"Email a link to the user to set their password" checkbox should not be available if user is being created into a 'Internal with LDAP authentication' directory.
!block-user-creation.png|thumbnail!

Similarly, if "Email a link to the user to set their password" is un-ticked, the password fields for users being created on the "Internal Delegated LDAP" are shown. However, for this use case, the password that is taken into account for login purposes is the one stored on the LDAP server. Therefore, those fields should _never_ be shown or enabled for this specific use case. That has been a source of confusion for a few customers as you can see [on this post in Answers|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/13405847/creating-users-in-stash-with-ldap-authentication]
!Create User - LDAP.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: "Email a link to the user to set their password" checkbox and password should not be available if user is being created into a LDAP Delegated scenario

The other nice feature the GitHub > Hipchat integration featured the Stash > Hipchat one doesn't is the ability for the commit comments (or PR comments) to be notified via Hipchat also (right now that's only sent via email if configured).

fields.description:
We have already contacted Atlassian Support due to not being able to get the "Development Panel" working inside Jira when Application Linking to Stash. 

They recommended creating the Application Links via HTTP (everything else runs on HTTPS via Apache Proxy)

The issue with this is when clicking something like "Create Branch", it uses the Application URL, not the Display URL which then requires the users to re-authenticate as it is a different domain. I think this will also stop us from using Secure Cookies when we implement Crowd.

Shouldn't the links in Jira through to Stash use Display URL, not Application URL? (... but behind the scenes it uses Application URL to gather that actual data presented in JIRA)
fields.summary: Use "Display URL" for Application Links

fields.description: Currently it looks like there is no way to restrict fork syncing to one or more branches. We have set up CI builds for every fork (per team) for a component, but the problem we have right now is that any change in upstream repository triggers a build on every fork as well, which causes the whole build agents pool to be exhausted. Of course we could find a workaround for this problem, but it would be nice to have an option in Stash to select branches which will be synced to the fork. It might be a good idea to allow usage of wildcards for that.
fields.summary: Fork syncing - allow to select specific branches to be synced

fields.description:
A common situation in review process is when the reviewer and the author discuss low-level decisions made in the code. The actionable units of review process are thus not comments, but _threads_. In the current UI, it's a pain for the pull request author to track threads that he has already done vs those that need to be done.

Raising issues in JIRA is not a solution: context is lost, and the process becomes more heavyweight. Most of the issues discussed are quite simple, so the overhead with entering an issue then transitioning it is not worth it.

A possible solution is read/unread markers on threads; ideal solution would include a place where unread threads are gathered.
fields.summary: Mark Threads as Read/Unread

fields.description:
When clicking the related jira task in Stash, some css seems to have gone missing. In my case, any tables lose their styling, and become quite hard to read.

We use Stash 2.11.2 and Jira v6.2.1#6256-sha1:89f5b3f)

Replication:

Create task in jira with tables in the description text.
Create commit or PR in Stash that references the jira task
Click the jira-task link in stash to reveal the jira task modal
fields.summary: Preserve styling in Jira task description when looking at the task from Stash

fields.description:
Hi,

we are currently testing Jira with Stash. Both applications are running on the same server and the Application Link is working now. But we need to use different "Display URLs" for the client browser. In Stash the "Display URL" is working correctly (fixed in https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-3651) and links to the Jira issue. But the same problem is now in Jira. The issue uses the Application Link and not the "Display URL" for images and public links. So if we click on the links in Jira we will be linked to the "localhost" and not "https://stash-test….".

Best Regards

Steffen
fields.summary: Application Links -> Display URL Property not used for browser client links
